title: Stanoje Glavaš
text:
Stanoje Stamatović (), known as Stanoje Glavaš (Станоје Главаш; 21 February 1763 – 15 February 1815) was a Serbian <a href="hajduk">hajduk</a> and hero in the <a href="First%20Serbian%20Uprising">First Serbian Uprising</a>.
Life.
Glavaš was born in 1763 in the village of <a href="Glibovac">Glibovac</a>, near <a href="Smederevska%20Palanka">Smederevska Palanka</a>, at the time part of the <a href="Sanjak%20of%20Smederevo">Sanjak of Smederevo</a>, <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. In his youth, he was a gentleman's tailor in Smederevska Palanka. He never married, which was unusual for small town business owners of the time in Serbia. For a time, he shared a house with a certain other confirmed bachelor, originally from <a href="Negotin">Negotin</a>, one Borisav Petrović, and they had a joint enterprise for constructing adobe houses. During this time <a href="Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e%20Petrovi%C4%87">Karađorđe Petrović</a> spent several months in Glavaš's house, either as an apprentice or as a <a href="hajduk">hajduk</a> in hiding during wintertime.
Later, Glavaš was the co-leader, with and , of a hajduk company based in <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian</a>-held <a href="Syrmia">Syrmia</a>, which frequently crossed the Ottoman border, and attacked <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> forces and caravans in the Sanjak of Smederevo in the 1790s (including <a href="Ko%C4%8Da%27s%20frontier%20rebellion">Koča's frontier rebellion</a>).
In 1804, at the eve of the <a href="First%20Serbian%20Uprising">First Serbian Uprising</a>, Glavaš, <a href="Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e">Karađorđe</a> and several other leaders gathered at <a href="Ora%C5%A1ac%2C%20Serbia">Orašac</a> to organize the revolt (see <a href="Serbian%20Revolution">Serbian Revolution</a>). Glavaš was suggested as leader. He refused the offer, opting for Karađorđe instead. In December 1806, commanders <a href="Vujica%20Vuli%C4%87evi%C4%87">Vujica</a>, <a href="Mladen%20Milovanovi%C4%87">Mladen Milovanović</a> and Glavaš commanded an army of 18,000 soldiers to defend the Serbs at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Deligrad">Battle of Deligrad</a>. The fight ended in Serbian victory, with <a href="Ibrahim%20Bushati">Ibrahim Bushati</a>, pasha of <a href="Shkod%C3%ABr">Shkodër</a>, signing a 6-week truce. He led a company of around 3,000 men which liberated <a href="Prokuplje">Prokuplje</a> and <a href="Kur%C5%A1umlija">Kuršumlija</a>. His company guarded the <a href="Morava%20Valley%20%28Serbia%29">Morava Valley</a> and fought the Ottomans in the mountains of <a href="Ni%C5%A1">Niš</a> and <a href="Novi%20Pazar">Novi Pazar</a> for two months before being captured. He was killed by the Ottomans on 15 February 1815, after the demise of <a href="Had%C5%BEi-Prodan%27s%20Uprising">Hadži-Prodan's Uprising</a>. His severed head was on display at the <a href="Kalemegdan">Kalemegdan</a> along with other Serbian leaders.
Legacy.
In his home town, there is a street and an <a href="Primary%20education">elementary school</a> named after him. He is the subject of a Serbian heroic play written by <a href="%C4%90ura%20Jak%C5%A1i%C4%87">Đura Jakšić</a>, which was widely shown throughout Serbia in the 19th century.
As a young widow, his mother remarried when he was about 12 or 13 (and that's when he became a tailor's apprentice) so he had several half-siblings, many years younger to whom he played a kind of fatherly role in his mature age, especially as he did not have his own family. He also had full (i.e. not half-) brother and sister from his mother's first marriage (to his father) and as a leader of the <a href="Serbian%20Revolution">Serbian Revolution</a>, he facilitated the marriage of his niece Marija (daughter of his brother) to <a href="Hajduk%20Veljko%20Petrovi%C4%87">Hajduk Veljko Petrović</a>, a fellow-hero and leader of the revolution (and there are surviving descendants of that union).
